articles.title: Apple stock slips after a big cut for iPhone 16 orders
articles.content: Shares of Apple (AAPL) closed down 2.16% on Wednesday after a report that the iPhone maker cut orders for its latest version by millions of units.

articles.title: Apple and Goldman Sachs ordered to pay $89M over Apple Card failures
articles.content: Apple and Goldman Sachs are being ordered by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to pay a combined $89 million in fines stemming from customer service issues with the Apple Card and regulatory violations.

articles.title: Apple and Goldman Sachs must pay $89 million for mishandling Apple Card transactions, CFPB orders
articles.content: A federal regulator on Wednesday ordered Apple and Goldman Sachs to pay a combined $89 million for deceiving consumers and mishandled transaction disputes of Apple Card customers.  Apple failed to send tens of thousands of Apple Card disputes to Goldman, and when such customer disputes were reported, the investment bank did not follow federal requirements for investigating, the agency said.

articles.title: Apple stock falls as confidence in iPhone 16 demand wavers
articles.content: Apple (AAPL) shares pull back as investors worry about iPhone 16 demand following analyst Ming-Chi Kuo sounding the alarm that orders were cut. Yahoo Finance’s Tech Editor Dan Howley sits down with Market Domination Hosts Julie Hyman and Josh Lipton to break down what investors need to know as the iPhone maker gears up to release Apple Intelligence. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here. This post was written by Naomi Buchanan.

articles.title: Why Apple (AAPL) Shares Are Sliding Today
articles.content: Shares of iPhone and iPad maker Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) fell 3.3% in the afternoon session after an industry survey conducted by TF International Securities analyst, Ming-Chi Kuo, revealed that iPhone 16 orders were cut by about 10 million units from the fourth quarter of 2024 through the first half of 2025. Kuo, known for his often spot-on predictions on Apple, is in the bearish camp, suggesting demand for the new iPhone models might not be as strong as initially anticipated.
